Experience PhD Candidate Stanford University September 2010  – Present (5 years) Swartz Laboratory, Dept. Chem Eng.; Advisor: Prof. James Swartz 
Developing a fully defined in vitro activation for the assembly and maturation of [Fe-Fe] hydrogenases to enable commercialization of sustainable hydrogen production from sunlight and electricity; Apply methods for protein engineering of hydrogenases for development of solar and glucose based H2-production, enable high throughput hydrogenase library screening, and improved in vivo and cell free hydrogenase expression and activation. Graduate Teaching Assistant Stanford University March 2013  –  June 2013  (4 months) Chemical Engineering 355: Advanced Biochemical Engineering,  
Served as teaching assistant for a 35 student graduate level advanced biochemical engineering course, covering recombinant DNA technology and synthetic biology (metabolic engineering), production of protein pharmaceuticals, fermentation technology and process development within the framework of current business and regulatory requirement; prepared and led a weekly discussion review section, held office hours twice a week, put together and graded homework assignments and exams. Graduate Teaching Assistant Stanford University March 2012  –  June 2012  (4 months) Chemical Engineering 25B: Biotechnology 
Teaching assistant for a 110 student undergraduate survey course in biotechnology covering genetic engineering, cell culture, protein production, pharmaceutics, genomics, viruses, gene therapy, immunology, antibodies, cloning, stem cells, transgenic animals, intellectual property, government regulation, and ethics; Held office hours weekly and prepared and led a discussion review session for students. Graduate Student Researcher Stanford University September 2011  –  March 2012  (7 months) Spormann Laboratory, Chemical Engineering; Investigated biogas production from waste water in microbial electrochemical cells; Created mutants to test electron transfer of E. coli for electro synthesis. Private Tutor, Athletic Academic Resource Center Stanford University September 2011  –  December 2011  (4 months) Engineering 30: Engineering Thermodynamics 
Worked with nine student athletes weekly to cover course content, including how energy and entropy principles are applied in thermodynamic analyses directed towards understanding the performances of engineering systems. Prepared extra practice problem sets, where methods and problems covered socially responsible economic generation and utilization of energy in central power generation plants, solar systems, refrigeration devices, and automobile, jet and gas-turbine engines. Created quantitative maps from magnetic resonance (MR) images of diffusion and T2 relaxation times in mouse models of the human U87 malignant glioma by writing MATLAB programs for analysis; measured physiological changes in tissue assessed for pre-clinical studies, including metabolite concentrations through magnetic resonance spectroscopy. Summary Genny Pang is a researcher with degrees in mechanical engineering, including her Ph.D. and M.S. from Stanford University and her B.S. from the University of California Los Angeles. Her research interests are in laser diagnostics and spectroscopy. She is currently an Alexander von Humboldt Fellow in at the Technical University of Munich. 
 
Previously at Stanford, Genny worked in the Thermal Sciences Division of the Mechanical Engineering Department in the laboratory of Professor Ronald K. Hanson where she focused on applying laser diagnostics to shock tube experiments for improving detailed chemical kinetic modeling on the combustion of petroleum-derived and renewable fuel sources. Prior to her work at Stanford, she investigated thermal, fluid, and chemical science research problems related to energy and aerospace applications at the National Renewable Energy Laboratory, NASA Langley Research Center, and NASA Ames Research Center. In addition to her research experience, Genny has held teaching assistant positions at Stanford for graduate-level courses in optical diagnostics and chemically reacting flows.  
 
Genny's other interests include mentoring youth in pre-college robotics programs, inspiring young women to become leaders in science and technology, and traveling to learn about the role of technology in different cultures. Her experiences include coaching an all-girls high school robotics team, volunteering through Latin America with energy-related projects, and judging youth technology challenges in Germany and the Netherlands. 
 
Specialties: 
•	Expert in the theory and application of optical diagnostics and thermal/energy systems  
•	Experienced in designing, modeling, operating, improving, troubleshooting and fixing problems in various electro-mechanical-optical-thermal systems 
•	Strong written and oral communicator with audiences of varying levels of scientific background Summary Genny Pang is a researcher with degrees in mechanical engineering, including her Ph.D. and M.S. from Stanford University and her B.S. from the University of California Los Angeles. Summary John is a registered US Patent Agent with over 18 years of experience in intellectual property and computer technology. John was trained in patent drafting and prosecution at a leading nationwide IP law firm. Before his transition to patent law, John worked for many years as a hardware engineer on microprocessor design teams at Intel and HP. John also spent several years designing UNIX software for high-speed printing applications. As a graduate teaching assistant at Stanford University, John taught classes relating to software algorithms, compilers, networking, distributed software, C++, and web site design, and gained valuable experience teaching technical concepts to non-technical audiences. John’s technical experience and legal background enable him to provide uniquely insightful technical opinions and comprehensive patent analyses which are highly respected throughout the industry. John is an inventor on 15 US patents, with 24 additional applications pending. Specialties:Patent analysis, claim-charting, valuation, reverse engineering, validity research, litigation support, computer hardware, computer software, computer architecture, microprocessors, digital circuits, gaming, 3D graphics, operating systems, databases, user interfaces, printer software, iPhone software applications Summary John is a registered US Patent Agent with over 18 years of experience in intellectual property and computer technology.
